@graph.articleBody: THE HISTORY OF PHOTOGRAPHY - ORIGIN OF PHOTOGRAPHY TO TODAYTable of Contents ShowINTRODUCTIONThe History of Photography: A Journey Through TimePhotography has transformed the way we see and document the world. From early light projections to the digital revolution, the history of photography showcases human ingenuity and artistic expression. Understanding its evolution offers insight into the technology shaping modern imaging. * The Birth of Photography : The camera obscura, described by Aristotle in the 4th century BCE, demonstrated how light projected an inverted image through a small hole. This concept evolved until Joseph Nic√©phore Ni√©pce captured the first permanent photograph in 1826 using heliography, requiring hours of exposure. In 1839, Louis Daguerre introduced the daguerreotype, a method that produced highly detailed images. Around the same time, William Henry Fox Talbot developed the calotype, allowing multiple prints from a single negative. * Technological Advances: The collodion wet plate process (1851) improved sharpness but required on-site development. George Eastman‚Äôs Kodak camera (1888) made photography accessible with roll film. By the 20th century, innovations like 35mm film (1925) and Kodachrome color film (1935) revolutionized documentary and artistic photography. Polaroid‚Äôs instant camera (1947) made photography even more immediate. * The Digital Age and AI Photography: Digital photography emerged in the 1970s, with Kodak engineer ntury, innovations like 35mm film (1925) and Kodachrome color film (1935) revolutionized documentary and artistic photography. Polaroid‚Äôs instant camera (1947) made photography even more immediate. * The Digital Age and AI Photography: Digital photography emerged in the 1970s, with Kodak engineer Steven Sasson inventing the first digital camera (1975). Over the next decades, digital sensors improved, leading to DSLR and mirrorless cameras. By the 2000s, digital cameras overtook film, and the iPhone (2007) brought photography to the masses. Today, AI-driven computational photography enhances images in real-time, making professional-quality photos possible on smartphones.Why Photography‚Äôs History Matters: Understanding the history of photography helps us appreciate the innovations shaping today‚Äôs technology. From early daguerreotypes to AI-powered cameras, photography continues to evolve while preserving the essence of storytelling and creativity. No matter the medium, the power of a captured moment remains timeless.----------------------------------------TIMELINE OF THE HISTORY OF PHOTOGRAPHY: FROM INVENTION TO PRESENT DAY----------------------------------------PRE-19TH CENTURY: THE FOUNDATIONSüìå 4th Century BCE ‚Äì Aristotle and ancient Chinese philosophers describe the camera obscura, an optical device that projects an inverted image of a scene.4TH CENTURY BCEThe Camera Obscura, described by Aristotle in the 4th century BCE, laid the foundation for photography. This optical marvel projected an inverted image through a small hole, but it lacked permanence. While it allowed for detailed observation, image quality was fleeting‚Äîno resolution, no pixels, just ephemeral light on a surface, awaiting the invention that could truly capture a moment.----------------------------------------16TH CENTURY ‚Äì THE ARTIST‚ÄôS TOOL: CAMERA OBSCURA REFINEMENTüìå 16th Century ‚Äì Artists use the camera obscura for accurate perspective drawing.By the 16th century, artists refined the camera obscura, using it to trace accurate compositions. Though still ephemeral, it improved clarity and sharpness, offering a pinhole-like projection of reality. However, it remained a fleeting vision‚Äîno pixels, no permanence, just light cast onto a surface, awaiting a means of preservation.----------------------------------------19TH CENTURY: THE BIRTH OF PHOTOGRAPHY1826‚Äì1827 ‚Äì THE FIRST PHOTOGRAPH: NI√âPCE‚ÄôS HELIOGRAPHüìå 1826‚Äì1827 ‚Äì Joseph Nic√©phore Ni√©pce creates the first permanent photograph, "View from the Window at Le Gras," using a process called heliography with a bitumen-coated plate.Joseph Nic√©phore Ni√©pce created the first permanent photograph using a bitumen-coated plate, exposed for hours in direct sunlight. The result was crude‚Äîlow contrast, grainy, and barely legible‚Äîyet revolutionary. This was the dawn of captured imagery, a faint, textured imprint of reality, akin to a primitive, ultra-low-resolution monochrome print.1839 ‚Äì DAGUERREOTYPE: A NEW LEVEL OF DETAILüìå 1839 ‚Äì Louis Daguerre invents the daguerreotype, the first publicly announced photographic process, producing a highly detailed, single-image on a silver-plated copper sheet.üìå 1839 ‚Äì The term "photography" is coined by Sir John Herschel, derived from the Greek words for "light" (phos) and "drawing" (graphe).Louis Daguerre introduced the daguerreotype, producing astonishing detail on a silver-plated copper sheet. While a single image only, its clarity f copper sheet.üìå 1839 ‚Äì The term "photography" is coined by Sir John Herschel, derived from the Greek words for "light" (phos) and "drawing" (graphe).Louis Daguerre introduced the daguerreotype, producing astonishing detail on a silver-plated copper sheet. While a single image only, its clarity far surpassed Ni√©pce‚Äôs work. Shadows and highlights emerged with depth, resembling a high-contrast black-and-white print‚Äîsharp but fragile, the first true glimpse of the world preserved in photographic form.1841 ‚Äì CALOTYPE: THE BIRTH OF NEGATIVESüìå 1841 ‚Äì William Henry Fox Talbot patents the calotype, an early paper-based negative-positive process, allowing multiple prints.William Henry Fox Talbot developed the calotype, pioneering the negative-positive process. Unlike the daguerreotype, this allowed for multiple prints, but images appeared softer, with less contrast. The detail was decent‚Äîthink early film grain rather than crisp edges‚Äîa vital step toward modern photography but still distant from the fine detail seen today.1851 ‚Äì WET PLATE COLLODION: A LEAP IN SHARPNESSüìå 1851 ‚Äì Frederick Scott Archer develops the collodion wet plate process, dramatically reducing exposure times and improving image sharpness.Frederick Scott Archer introduced the collodion wet plate, drastically improving image quality. Compared to calotypes, this offered sharper details and richer contrast, akin to moving from soft-focus film to razor-sharp monochrome prints. However, it required complex handling, making it a tool for dedicated photographers rather than everyday users.1888 ‚Äì KODAK‚ÄôS ROLL FILM REVOLUTIONüìå 1888 ‚Äì George Eastman introduces the Kodak camera, revolutionizing photography with roll film and the slogan ‚ÄúYou press the button, we do the rest.‚ÄùGeorge Eastman‚Äôs Kodak camera changed everything: roll film meant photography for all. While image quality was softer than glass plate photography, it introduced portability. Resolution was comparable to early compact film cameras‚Äîgrainy yet recognisable, marking the birth of mass-market photography with the iconic slogan: ‚ÄúYou press the button, we do the rest.‚Äù1895 ‚Äì THE FIRST X-RAY PHOTOGRAPH: SEEING BEYOND LIGHTüìå 1895 ‚Äì Wilhelm R√∂ntgen takes the first X-ray photograph, expanding photography beyond the visible spectrum.Wilhelm R√∂ntgen captured the first X-ray image, revealing a hidden world beneath the skin. Unlike traditional photography, this produced stark, ghostly skeletal images with extreme contrast‚Äîa precursor to medical imaging rather than artistic photography, but still a major milestone in the evolution of photographic technology.----------------------------------------20TH CENTURY: THE RISE OF MODERN PHOTOGRAPHY1907 ‚Äì AUTOCHROME LUMI√àRE: THE FIRST COLOUR PROCESSüìå 1907 ‚Äì The first commercially available color process, Autochrome Lumi√®re, is introduced.The Lumi√®re brothers introduced Autochrome Lumi√®re, bringing colour photography to life. Unlike modern vibrant images, early Autochrome prints were muted, grainy, and dreamlike, similar to a hand-tinted postcard rather than true-to-life colour. Though revolutionary, it lacked the crisp, saturated hues seen in later film photography.1925 ‚Äì THE LEICA I: PIONEERING 35MM PHOTOGRAPHYüìå 1913 ‚Äì The Leitz Camera (Leica) is developed, pioneering 35mm photography and portability.üìå 1925 ‚Äì The Leica I is released, becoming the standard for 35mm photography.The release of the Leica I changed photography fo later film photography.1925 ‚Äì THE LEICA I: PIONEERING 35MM PHOTOGRAPHYüìå 1913 ‚Äì The Leitz Camera (Leica) is developed, pioneering 35mm photography and portability.üìå 1925 ‚Äì The Leica I is released, becoming the standard for 35mm photography.The release of the Leica I changed photography forever. Compact, discreet, and fast, it made high-quality street and reportage photography possible. Compared to larger formats, resolution was lower but sharp enough for publication‚Äîlike stepping from a large plate camera to a sleek, full-frame DSLR equivalent for its time.1935 ‚Äì KODACHROME: THE FIRST WIDELY AVAILABLE COLOUR FILMüìå 1935 ‚Äì Kodachrome film is introduced, the first widely available color film.Kodachrome brought rich, vivid colour to mainstream photography. Compared to Autochrome, it offered greater sharpness and tonal depth, akin to stepping from a faded pastel to a high-quality film scan. For decades, it remained the benchmark for colour photography, with deep blacks, fine grain, and a timeless, cinematic quality.1947 ‚Äì POLAROID INSTANT PHOTOGRAPHY: IMMEDIATE RESULTSüìå 1947 ‚Äì Polaroid introduces instant photography, invented by Edwin Land, with the first instant camera arriving in 1948.Edwin Land‚Äôs Polaroid gave photographers instant gratification. Early prints were soft, with limited dynamic range, like an early inkjet photo compared to a high-resolution film print. Yet, it revolutionised photography, offering a snapshot of life in real-time, making it the precursor to today‚Äôs instant digital sharing.1957 ‚Äì THE FIRST DIGITAL IMAGE: THE PIXEL IS BORNüìå 1957 ‚Äì The first digital image is created by Russell Kirsch, scanning a black-and-white photograph into a computer.The first digital image, scanned in 1957, was only 176x176 pixels‚Äîa far cry from today‚Äôs megapixel standards. It was grainy, low contrast, and monochrome, much like an early fax image. Yet, it marked the birth of digital photography, proving that images could exist outside of film and paper.1963 ‚Äì KODAK INSTAMATIC: SIMPLICITY FOR THE MASSESüìå 1963 ‚Äì Kodak introduces Instamatic cameras, making photography accessible to a mass audience.The Kodak Instamatic made photography easier than ever, with a point-and-shoot simplicity that mimicked today's smartphone cameras. Image quality was acceptable but unrefined, like a disposable film camera print‚Äîgrainy, soft, but perfectly suited for casual photography.1975 ‚Äì THE FIRST DIGITAL CAMERA: A NEW ERA BEGINSüìå 1975 ‚Äì Steven Sasson at Kodak invents the first digital camera, capturing a 0.01-megapixel image on a cassette tape.Steven Sasson‚Äôs prototype digital camera captured an image at 0.01 megapixels (100x100 pixels), recording onto a cassette tape. The result? Blurry, blocky, and nearly unrecognisable compared to film, but the concept was game-changing‚Äîa true first step into a pixel-based future.1981 ‚Äì SONY MAVICA: THE FIRST ELECTRONIC STILL CAMERAüìå 1981 ‚Äì Sony releases the Mavica, the first electronic still camera, storing images digitally but displaying them on a screen.The Sony Mavica introduced electronic still photography, but resolution was still weak‚Äîthink early VGA computer graphics (0.3 megapixels), with washed-out tones and limited dynamic range. Still, it set the stage for true digital cameras.1987 ‚Äì CANON EOS: AUTOFOCUS REINVENTEDüìå 1987 ‚Äì Canon introduces the EOS system, marking the transition to modern autofocus SLRs.Canon‚Äôs EOS system revolutionised ter graphics (0.3 megapixels), with washed-out tones and limited dynamic range. Still, it set the stage for true digital cameras.1987 ‚Äì CANON EOS: AUTOFOCUS REINVENTEDüìå 1987 ‚Äì Canon introduces the EOS system, marking the transition to modern autofocus SLRs.Canon‚Äôs EOS system revolutionised photography, integrating fast, accurate autofocus. This marked a shift towards modern DSLRs, with image quality comparable to high-end film cameras‚Äîsharp, detailed, and professional-grade.1991 ‚Äì KODAK DCS-100: THE FIRST PROFESSIONAL DIGITAL SLRüìå 1991 ‚Äì Kodak launches the first professional digital SLR, the DCS-100, at 1.3 megapixels.At 1.3 megapixels, the Kodak DCS-100 delivered a huge leap in digital quality. Compared to film, it was still lacking in resolution and dynamic range, but it proved digital SLRs could compete in professional settings.----------------------------------------21ST CENTURY: THE DIGITAL REVOLUTION & AI PHOTOGRAPHY2000 ‚Äì THE FIRST CAMERA PHONE: A LOW-RES REVOLUTIONüìå 2000 ‚Äì Sharp introduces the first camera phone, the J-SH04, starting the era of mobile photography.The Sharp J-SH04 introduced mobile photography with a 0.1-megapixel sensor. Quality was extremely low‚Äîpixelated and washed-out, akin to a basic webcam image, but it laid the foundation for the smartphone revolution.2004 ‚Äì THE FALL OF FILM: DIGITAL TAKES OVERüìå 2004 ‚Äì Film camera production declines significantly as digital cameras overtake film in sales.By 2004, digital camera sales overtook film, marking the true transition to the digital era. Early digital compact cameras offered 3-5 megapixels, close to 35mm film in resolution but lacking its depth and richness.2007 ‚Äì THE IPHONE: A POCKET CAMERA REVOLUTIONüìå 2007 ‚Äì Apple launches the first iPhone, revolutionizing smartphone photography and leading to the rise of social media-driven photography.The first iPhone had a 2-megapixel camera, far below DSLRs but a step beyond early camera phones. Image quality was basic‚Äîlike an entry-level compact camera, yet it marked the beginning of photography‚Äôs shift to always-on connectivity.2012 ‚Äì THE RISE OF MIRRORLESS CAMERASüìå 2012 ‚Äì Mirrorless cameras gain popularity, challenging DSLRs with compact designs and high performance.With compact bodies and DSLR-quality sensors, mirrorless cameras like the Sony NEX-7 proved that portability didn‚Äôt mean sacrificing image quality. At 24 megapixels, they rivalled professional setups while remaining lightweight.2017 ‚Äì AI-POWERED COMPUTATIONAL PHOTOGRAPHYüìå 2017 ‚Äì AI-powered computational photography, such as Google‚Äôs Pixel HDR+, enhances mobile photography with software processing.Google‚Äôs HDR+ technology changed mobile photography. AI-enhanced images offered greater dynamic range, noise reduction, and detail, making smartphones compete with DSLRs for everyday photography.2021 ‚Äì AI & DEEPFAKE PHOTOGRAPHYüìå 2021 ‚Äì AI-generated images and deepfake technology become mainstream, challenging traditional photography ethics.AI-generated imagery blurred the lines between reality and fiction. With machine learning, photorealistic images at ultra-high resolutions could be created entirely without cameras, redefining what photography even means.2024 ‚Äì SMARTPHONES SURPASS TRADITIONAL CAMERAS.üìå 2024-Present ‚Äì Smartphone cameras surpass traditional cameras for general use, while AI, machine learning, and computational photography redefine what cameras can do.AI-dri
